Judge Alito: "If settled means that it is a precedent... and all of the factors that I‚Äôve mentioned come into play, including the reaffirmation and all of that, then it is a precedent that is protected, entitled to respect under the doctrine of stare decisis in that way." /6

Judge Alito: "When [Justices] examine a question and they reach a conclusion, I think that‚Äôs entitled to considerable respect, and of course, the more times that happens, the more respect the decision is entitled to, and that‚Äôs my view of that." /5

Judge Alito: "The more often a decision is reaffirmed, the more people tend to rely on it... I think stare decisis reflects the view that there is wisdom embedded in decisions that have been made by prior Justices who take the same oath and are scholars and are conscientious." /4

Judge Alito: "[Roe] has been challenged on a number of occasions... and the Supreme Court has reaffirmed the decision... and I think that when a decision is challenged and it is reaffirmed that strengthens its value as stare decisis for at least two reasons." /3

Senator Durbin in 2006: "John Roberts said that Roe v. Wade is the settled law of the land. Do you believe it is the settled law of the land?"
